column4: ever since switching back to the nv driver, my system is quite laggy in video performance.. any suggestions on what to check? also how do I stop the nvidia kernel module loading automatically at boot (without removing restricted modules that is)?
Try uninstalling the nvidia binary blob.
you mean nvidia-glx? gone already
You may then remove/rename the kernel module, it doesn't hurt to do it.
yeah I guess..
The vn driver doesn't support 3D Acceleration.
who's talking about 3d.. this is plain 2d stuff and it's dog-slow
That's pretty much all it can do, from what I perceived.
lag of up to 2 seconds after a mouse click on a scroll bar before the screen updates
That's much slower than it should be, what web pages were you browsing ?
pretty much anything.
The performance would drop drastically if the pages contain Flash or heavy gif/jpeg files.
from theregister to news sites to anything. it's not restricted to web browsing.. affects kmail, evolution, even xchat
Did it work fine when you first install Ubuntu ?
I don't remember.. that was back in the days of Hoary
and I seem to remember the first thing I did was install the nvidia binary driver

I'm afraid I can not help if it has anything to do with compatibility, if the nvidia 3D driver package (from their site) is not causing you problem (it does to me though - unstable for some people), try using it.
see the topic as to why I uninstalled it.
The nv driver should not causing troubles even in 1280x1024x32, as far as I know.
1440x900x32 at the moment, so yeah
Sorry for not be able to help you any further. If reducing the resolution/bitrate works, perhaps that's your video adapter could not handle screen resolution that big.
well it's the same size as before.. and since it's an LCD, going lower is not an option
High resolution for a 3D driver is not an issue (as you said you first installed nvidia-glx back then), but it should'nt be a surprise when using the default nv driver.
